title: 108_hr1997
content: The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004, also known as "Laci and Conner's Law," amends Title 18 of the United States Code to include a new chapter, "Protection of Unborn Children," which aims to protect unborn children. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004, also known as "Laci and Conner's Law," establishes a separate offense for causing harm to a child in utero. The punishment for this offense is similar to the punishment for causing harm to the mother. It does not require proof of knowledge of the pregnancy or intent to harm the unborn child. If the conduct results in the intentional killing of the unborn child, the offender is punished as if they had killed a human being. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 establishes a separate offense for causing harm to an unborn child. The punishment for this offense is similar to causing harm to the mother. If the conduct results in the intentional killing of the unborn child, the offender is punished as if they had killed a human being. The death penalty is not imposed for this offense. Various sections of the law are referenced for prosecution. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 establishes a separate offense for causing harm to an unborn child, defining an unborn child as a member of the species homo sapiens at any stage of development in the womb. This Act does not permit prosecution for conduct related to abortion with proper consent, medical treatment of the pregnant woman or her unborn child, or prosecution of a woman with respect to her unborn child. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 establishes a separate offense for causing harm to an unborn child, defining an unborn child as a member of the species homo sapiens at any stage of development in the womb. The military justice system has been amended to include protection for unborn children under section 919a. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 creates a separate offense for causing harm to an unborn child, without requiring proof of knowledge or intent. If the conduct intentionally kills the unborn child, different punishments apply. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 establishes penalties for intentionally killing an unborn child, with specific punishments outlined. The death penalty is not applicable for offenses under this act. Prosecution is not permitted for actions related to abortion with proper consent, medical treatment of the pregnant woman or her unborn child, or for any woman regarding her unborn child. The term "unborn child" refers to a child in utero. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 establishes penalties for intentionally killing an unborn child, with specific punishments outlined. Consent is implied by law for medical treatment of the pregnant woman or her unborn child, or for any woman regarding her unborn child. The term "unborn child" refers to a child in utero, defined as a member of the species homo sapiens at any stage of development.
